1: <sup>1</sup> My son, keep my words, and lay up my commandments with thee.
2: <sup>2</sup> Keep my commandments, and live; and my law as the apple of thine eye.
3: <sup>3</sup> Bind them upon thy fingers, write them upon the table of thine heart.
4: <sup>4</sup> Say unto wisdom, Thou art my sister; and call understanding thy kinswoman:
5: <sup>5</sup> That they may keep thee from the strange woman, from the stranger which flattereth with her words.
6: <sup>6</sup> For at the window of my house I looked through my casement,
7: <sup>7</sup> And beheld among the simple ones, I discerned among the youths, a young man void of understanding,
8: <sup>8</sup> Passing through the street near her corner; and he went the way to her house,
9: <sup>9</sup> In the twilight, in the evening, in the black and dark night:
10: <sup>10</sup> And, behold, there met him a woman with the attire of an harlot, and subtil of heart.
11: <sup>11</sup> (She is loud and stubborn; her feet abide not in her house:
12: <sup>12</sup> Now is she without, now in the streets, and lieth in wait at every corner.)
13: <sup>13</sup> So she caught him, and kissed him, and with an impudent face said unto him,
14: <sup>14</sup> I have peace offerings with me; this day have I payed my vows.
15: <sup>15</sup> Therefore came I forth to meet thee, diligently to seek thy face, and I have found thee.
16: <sup>16</sup> I have decked my bed with coverings of tapestry, with carved works, with fine linen of Egypt.
17: <sup>17</sup> I have perfumed my bed with myrrh, aloes, and cinnamon.
18: <sup>18</sup> Come, let us take our fill of love until the morning: let us solace ourselves with loves.
19: <sup>19</sup> For the goodman is not at home, he is gone a long journey:
20: <sup>20</sup> He hath taken a bag of money with him, and will come home at the day appointed.
21: <sup>21</sup> With her much fair speech she caused him to yield, with the flattering of her lips she forced him.
22: <sup>22</sup> He goeth after her straightway, as an ox goeth to the slaughter, or as a fool to the correction of the stocks;
23: <sup>23</sup> Till a dart strike through his liver; as a bird hasteth to the snare, and knoweth not that it is for his life.
24: <sup>24</sup> Hearken unto me now therefore, O ye children, and attend to the words of my mouth.
25: <sup>25</sup> Let not thine heart decline to her ways, go not astray in her paths.
26: <sup>26</sup> For she hath cast down many wounded: yea, many strong men have been slain by her.
27: <sup>27</sup> Her house is the way to hell, going down to the chambers of death.
